docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Siphoning Money From Medicaid'' (editorial, Sept. 11):
docs.abstract: Greater New York Hospital Association president Kenneth E Raske letter on Sept 11 editorial that urged closing of loophole in Medicaid law that is being used by 17 states, including New York, to inflate their costs and extract more federal money than they are entitled to; says if Health Care Financing Administration decides to implement regulations changing Medicaid reimbursement rules, vital health insurance programs for low-income New Yorkers will be jeopardized
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    Re ''Siphoning Money From Medicaid'' (editorial, Sept. 11):

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. John W. Rowe, 56, chief executive of Mount Sinai N.Y.U. MedicalCenter and Health System, was cho-sen this month to be president andchief executive of Aetna U.S. Health-care. I HAD odd jobs as a student. I worked for the Postal Service, I worked for an office cleaningcompany. I had one really good job, helping a church group with a tour of Europe. Each night, I would read upon where we were going the next day. I remember discussing Cellinis ''Perseus''after having read about it for the first time 12 hours previously. But these jobs were a matter of con-venience during my education andtraining, which was long and rigorous. During my internship, I oftenworked all night, every other night.Once I fell asleep at the dinner table,and my wife took a picture of mewith my face in the supper dish. My first real job wasn't until 1976, when I was 32 and by then had three children. I got a job as a juniorand the emphasis is on junior faculty member at Harvard Medical School. I was assigned to develop anacademic research and teaching program on aging the first ever. I had my own research laboratory, and I could design and conduct my own experiments. While this was agreat honor, to be made chief of a new unit, the downside was that the initial pay was so bad I couldn't support my family and had to moonlightas a nephrologist at a dialysis clinic. It was a steep uphill battle to establish a new area of medicine in aschool that had been around for hundreds of years. I felt like Sisyphus, pushing the rock uphill every day only to have it roll back down. Overtime we built the nation's largest academic research program on aging. As for Aetna, it looks very much to me like my first job at Harvard. Health insurance is broken in this country, and we need to re-engineer it. I dont know if it will be like pushing a rock uphill; but if it is, I am prepared.

headline.kicker: MY FIRST JOB: JOHN W. ROWE

docs.lead_paragraph: Kari Andrea Van Nevel, a daughter of Lois E. Van Nevel and J. Paul Van Nevel of Potomac, Md., was married yesterday to Matthew Hall Buckard, the son of Penelope D. Buckard and Donald L. Buckard of Watchung, N.J. The Rev. Ervin Brown performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in St. Michaels, Md. Mrs. Buckard, 33, is the senior director of product operations at ClickThings! an Internet company in New York that helps businesses create, manage and edit their own Web sites. She graduated from Mount Holyoke College and received an M.B.A. from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. Her father, who retired as the associate director for communications at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md., is a consultant on public relations for health-care organizations. Her mother, also retired, was a teacher at the Seven Locks Baptist Nursery School in Potomac.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I'm sure all of us that had the fortune of knowing Peter Chow are thankful you wrote about what a wonderful person he was. The saddest part is that many of us did not know that he suffered from asthma. He always had a kind word for his customers and would never mention his troubles.

headline.main: More to Say on 'Pursuit of Less'; Laundry Kept On Going After a Father Died

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A Sept. 10 Week in Review article reports that companies are ''abandoning H.M.O.'s for preferred provider organizations -- doctor networks that agree to reduced rates for their services.'' It also quotes Robert D. Reischauer, president of the Urban Institute, as saying, ''Don't be surprised if this bubble pops, too.''

docs.lead_paragraph: With so much attention focused these days on the issues and personalities in the presidential race, it is too often forgotten that a record fund-raising campaign is being waged by the candidates with far less public scrutiny. Once again big unregulated donations from corporations, unions and rich individuals are pouring into party treasuries and being used for campaigns in violation of the campaign laws. Whether it is the Democrats getting money from trial lawyers for killing a bill that would curb personal-injury lawsuits, or Republicans getting money from corporations to get such a bill passed, the ''soft money'' loophole has corrupted the whole political system. According to Common Cause, the parties raised $256 million in soft money in the first 18 months of this election cycle, more than 80 percent ahead of what they raised in the comparable period of time four years ago. The White House, moreover, has acknowledged that President Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton are once again having sleepovers for major donors to Mrs. Clinton's Senate race. The Times reported last week that the Democrats had raised $4 million in huge chunks from a handful of powerful Texas trial lawyers in the years since Mr. Clinton's veto of legislation that would have curbed the amount of money people could win in lawsuits over faulty products. A Justice Department investigation is under way to see if any bribery statutes were violated.
docs.abstract: Editorial on big unregulated donations from corporations, unions and rich individuals that are once again pouring into political party treasuries, to be used for campaigns in violation of campaign laws; says that, short of Congressional action, courts should step in to stop corrupt practices

docs.lead_paragraph: Schools Chancellor Harold O. Levy has hired the elder daughter of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Democratic vice-presidential candidate, to help match city schools with corporate partners that can provide volunteers and financial support. Rebecca Lieberman, 31, will start working full time at the Board of Education after Election Day, said David Klasfeld, the deputy chancellor. She will earn $75,000 a year and will work for Freda Plesser, whom Mr. Levy hired last month to be the board's chief executive for corporate partnerships at a salary of $150,500.

headline.main: Schools Chancellor Hires Lieberman's Daughter for Project

docs.lead_paragraph: The Republican campaign of Gov. George W. Bush and Dick Cheney has begun broadcasting a commercial, ''Compare,'' in 18 states in its effort to take the offensive on the issues. It takes aim at Vice President Al Gore's stands on a prescription drug benefit in Medicare, on education and on tax cuts. PRODUCER -- Maverick Media

docs.lead_paragraph: Vice President Al Gore concluded a tightly controlled week devoted to fund-raising and education policy by telling an enthusiastic crowd of students at Howard University today that improving schools and access to college must become a major federal priority in coming years. Mr. Gore pointed out that the parents of school-age children now make up a smaller percentage of the overall voting population than ever before because the average age of Americans is rising and young adults, though a growing part of the population, are starting families later. That, he said, has undercut political support for the local tax increases and bond issues that typically pay for significant school improvements.

headline.main: On Campus, Gore Stresses Need to Invest In Education

docs.lead_paragraph: A judge ordered Buffalo's public school teachers back to their classrooms yesterday after they announced a strike in the hour before school started for the second time in a weeklong and increasingly bitter dispute. The roughly 4,000 teachers in the Buffalo school system, the state's second largest, had returned to classes earlier this week as a good-faith gesture while strike negotiations continued, and the school district believed that the two sides were within whispering distance of a settlement late Wednesday night.

headline.main: Buffalo Teachers Walk Out for a 2nd Time in a Week

docs.abstract: Justice Kevin M Dillon orders Buffalo's public school teachers back to their classrooms after they announce a strike in the hour before school starts on Sept 14; bus drivers serve their routes as usual to tell parents waiting with their children at bus stops that school is canceled and to pick up any children waiting alone to deliver them to school, where officials called their parents; photo (M)
